Module mesakit.map.measurements
Package com.telenav.mesakit.map.measurements.geographic

Class Angle

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.mesakit.map.measurements.geographic.Angle
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.NextValue<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.factory.MapFactory<Long,​Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Arithmetic<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Castable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.CastTrait, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.DoubleQuantizable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.IntegerNumeric<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Maximizable<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Minimizable<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Quantizable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.string.Stringable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.string.StringSource, com.telenav.kivakit.validation.Validatable, Serializable, Comparable<Angle>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Heading, Height, Latitude, Longitude, Slope, Width
public class Angle extends Object implements com.telenav.kivakit.validation.Validatable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.IntegerNumeric<Angle>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.string.Stringable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Quantizable, Serializable
An angle value represented between -360 and 360 degrees. Note that an angle of -45 degrees is seen as being less than 15 degrees. In other words the values are not normalized for comparison.

DM5, DM6 and DM7

DM5, DM6 and DM7 are measurements of accuracy (of angles, including latitudes and longitudes). DM5 values (DM = Decimal) have 5 places after the decimal, and DM6 and DM7 have 6 and 7 places, respectively. For example:

  • DM5 - 47.12389
  • DM6 - 47.123895
  • DM7 - 47.1238951

Creating Angles

Several useful constants are provided, and factory methods create angles for different units (subclasses of Angle will have their own construction methods):

  • degrees(double)
  • microdegrees(int)
  • nanodegrees(long)
  • radians(double)

Operations

  • absoluteDifference(Angle)
  • bisect(Angle, Chirality)
  • dividedBy(double)
  • dividedBy(Angle)
  • times(double)
  • plus(Angle)
  • maximum(Angle)
  • minimum(Angle)
  • projectionOnEarthSurface()
  • reversed()

Checks

  • isAcute()
  • isBetween(Angle, Angle, Chirality)
  • isClose(Angle, Angle)
  • isCloseOrReverseIsClose(Angle, Angle)
  • isMaximum()

    • difference

      public Angle difference​(Angle that, Angle.Chirality type)
      Computes the difference between this angle and another angle in various different ways.

      Chirality.CLOCKWISE - Computes the difference from this angle to that angle in the clockwise direction, possibly crossing the 360 degree line. For example, the difference between 10 degrees and 20 degrees is 10 degrees. The difference between 355 degrees and 5 degrees in the clockwise direction is also 10 degrees.

      Chirality.COUNTERCLOCKWISE - Computes the difference from this angle to that angle in the counterclockwise direction, possibly crossing the 360 degree line. For example, the counterclockwise difference between 20 degrees and 10 degrees is 10 degrees. The counterclockwise difference between 5 degrees and 355 degrees is also 10 degrees.

      Chirality.SMALLEST - Returns the smallest of the clockwise and the counterclockwise differences

      Parameters:
      that - The other angle
      Returns:
      The difference between the two angles as an angle

      public boolean isBetween​(Angle a, Angle b, Angle.Chirality type)
      Parameters:
      a - The first angle defining the range.
      b - The second angle defining the range.
      Returns:
      True indicates that the angle is greater than or equal to the minimum bound and less than or equal to the upper bound.
